answers.answer: I don't remember seeing your name around here before. If not, welcome aboard. I can offer only moral support until the folks who know their stuff come online. They aren't out this evening. There are so many new folks on the forum, and it seems some are slipping through the cracks and feeling let down. So I seem to be this evening's welcome wagon!If I'm not mistaken, 35 years of epilepsy may be able to cause some of the findings you describe, but I will leave that to our medical folks when they return.  Hang in there - help will be along, hopefully soon. Your appt is just around the corner!Penn
bumping you back to page 1. wow there was alot of action on the forum today!

Hello Penn! Thanks for the Welcome! No, I have never been here before. The internet led me to this forum when I typed in a few things from my MRI to figure out what it means. Anything I seemed to find kept leading back to MS. I don't know much about it at all....I just know that my MRI findings brought me here. Can anyone help with my MRI at all?

Welcome to our cyber family.Some of the findings could be consistant with a demyelinating disorders.I'm not familiar with epilepsy and what long term effects it can leave on the brain.There is a post that Quix our board retired DR(pediatrics) has posted on MRI's,this info may help.Hopefully you can get some answers tomorrow.T
What caused you to get an MRI of the brain?
I had multiple seziures and I was in the hospital for 6 days. two different hospitals . 3 days in one and 3 days in another. What is demyelinating disorders?

Could someone get these spots from Diabetes type 2 I wonder? I looked up demyelinating disorders and found that it can have something to do with our eyes as well as MS. I have type 2 Diabetes diagnosed in March.

Well, you sound like you have lots going on! I can't help you with the medical stuff, but I can welcome you to this forum. I have learned a lot here from all the experienced, knowledgable folks who do their best to answer your questions. Good luck!

demyleniating is the broad term that describes MS and some other related but less likely but  similar conditions,Besides MS, lesions can be caused by Ischaemia (small strokes), infections, conditions with nflammation of the blood vessels (vasculitis) and multiple tumours, trauma (injury). There really are too many to enumerate.

Well, I saw my new Dr today and I have to say that it was the worst Dr visit I have ever had. I am a new patient to this Dr and he was in the room for 15 minutes! He didn't even ask me any questions! I had to ask 3 times what he thought about my MRI and his words were "It's nothing it's nothing" WOW! Now I have to start all over and find a new Dr. I'm so frustrated. But thanks to everyone who replied. Thanks for your time! :)

Welcome to the Forum!!  I am sorry about your Dr. visit today.  Sounds like you went to a neurologist, right?  There are alot of us here who have had bad neuro visits, so many in fact that we have named them "weanies" and we have a Weanie Roast every Friday night to cyber roast these horrific doctors who prefer to practice incompetence, laziness and judgement rather than good medicine.The good neurologists may appear to be extint but they are out there, just seam to be harder to find than these weanies!  Your weanie has earned the distinction of being our first to be roasted this Friday night.  I am so sorry about your seizures and your hospital stay, I hope you are feeling a bit better!Take care and again, Welcome!Kristin

Thanks Kristin!!! Lets get him roasted!! What a waste of $30.00! He isn't a Neuro, he is an internist. He is my HMO main Dr who reffers me all over the place. He did give me a refferal for a Neuro whom I have to call & set up an appt. Maybe he will be better suited for me!!!! Lets cross our fingers!

question: Well, I know a lot of people ask these same questions, but I have come to learn that no one MRI is like any other. So here are my findings: There are several tiny punctate foci of abnormal signal predominately located within the subcortical white matter of the cerebral hemispheres bilaterally but are also noted within the deeper centrum semiovale and periventricular white matter. These are more prominent in the frontal lobes. I do not have nor have I ever had a migraine. I have had Epilepsy for 35 years. I appreciate any lamens terms I can get. I feel so lost. I see my new Dr on the 7th of November. Thank you so much!
title: MRI question
